title: The Genetics of Myasthenia Gravis

content: Living with myasthenia gravis (MG) means navigating constant uncertainty. Symptoms flare out of nowhere, your body decides its own rules, and rest becomes more essential than optional.
But a question that follows me is: Why me?

When I was first diagnosed, that question echoed louder than anything else. Was it something I did? Something I ate? Stress? Bad luck? And more recently, I’ve started asking: Was it written in my genes?

The truth is, MG isn’t as straightforward as some other autoimmune conditions. It doesn’t tend to run in families the way Hashimoto’s thyroiditis or lupus might. Most of us with MG don’t have a parent or sibling who has it.
But that doesn’t mean genetics play no role.

What I’ve come to understand is that MG is likely the result of a perfect storm. A mix of genetic susceptibility, environmental triggers, immune system quirks, and a bit of mystery science still hasn’t cracked.

content: There are genetic markers that appear more commonly in people with MG, like certain HLA (human leukocyte antigen) types. These are like ID badges for your immune system, helping it recognize what’s you and what’s not.
When these markers are slightly off, your immune system can get confused. And sometimes that confusion means it starts attacking your own muscles, as it does in MG.

But knowing that isn’t exactly comforting. Truth is, most people with these genes don’t develop MG. So it’s not a direct cause. It’s more like a nudge in the wrong direction, waiting for something like a virus, a hormonal shift, or intense stress to push things over the edge.
And that’s the bit that sits weirdly with me.

Because you start to wonder about all those moments before diagnosis. Was it the stress I didn’t process? The burnout I ignored? The way I pushed myself too hard for too long? Did something in me crack open the door, and did my body walk through it?
There’s no definite answer. And maybe that’s the hardest part.

content: Something else I find fascinating (and a little infuriating) is about 80% of autoimmune patients are female. That’s not a small margin. That’s the overwhelming majority. Which naturally raises more questions.

Why are women more prone to autoimmunity? Is it hormones? Genetics? Or could it also be the chronic emotional load many women carry quietly for years? Studies have linked long-term, unprocessed stress to immune dysfunction, especially when emotions are regularly suppressed or dismissed.
And then there’s your gut. I didn’t realize just how much of your immune system is based there, around 70%, in fact. So if your gut is struggling, your immune system probably is too.

Things like diet, antibiotics, infections, stress, and sleep shape the balance of bacteria in your gut, which in turn affects inflammation, immunity, and potentially the development of autoimmune conditions like MG.
Understanding these pieces doesn’t give me a time machine. But it does help me make peace with the fact this wasn’t my fault. It wasn’t a punishment. It wasn't a weakness.

content: It was biology, doing what biology sometimes does, making strange, unpredictable choices.

That said, knowing about contributing factors helps me in practical ways, too. I’ve started being more curious about my family’s autoimmune history, even conditions that seem totally unrelated. I pay more attention to how I manage stress. I focus more on supporting my gut, reducing inflammation, and listening to my body when it’s begging me to slow down.
The little threads that tug on your immune system behind the scenes deserve more care than I used to give them.
And I try to remember this: Genes aren’t a sentence. They’re a suggestion. A starting point.

They may load the gun, but they don’t pull the trigger. There’s still so much I can influence. The way I eat. The way I rest. The way I speak to myself when I’m flaring and frustrated. The boundaries I set. The peace I protect. And the community I build around me, people who understand, support, and stay.

content: If you’re reading this and you’re living with MG, it’s okay to not have all the answers. You don’t need to solve the mystery of your illness to validate your experience.
It’s real. It’s hard. And it’s not your fault.

Whether your genes played a small role, a big one, or none at all, you’re not broken. You’re navigating a body that needs a little more care, a little more compassion, and a lot more rest than some. And that’s not a weakness. That’s wisdom.

So if the “why me” question pops into your mind from time to time, that’s okay. Let it. Then breathe, soften, and remind yourself: I may not know exactly how I got here, but I know how to take care of myself now that I am.
And that, in itself, is powerful.
